elements.content: Five Cu(II)/benzoate/4,4‘-bipy complexes, namely, [Cu(H2O)(benzoate)2(4,4‘-bipy)2](benzoic acid)2·(4,4‘-bipy) (1), [Cu2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)3]·(H2O)9 (2), [Cu2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)3] (3), [Cu3(H2O)4(benzoate)6(4,4‘-bipy)4.5]·(4,4‘-bipy)·(H2O)5 (4), and [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)2] (5) (4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine), have been synthesized through hydrothermal reaction of copper(II) nitrate, benzoic acid, and 4,4‘-bipyridine under different pH conditions. The diverse product structures show the marked sensitivity of the structural chemistry of the aromatic carboxylate ligand to synthesis conditions. Complex 1, which exhibits a zero-dimensional (0D) structure of mononuclear copper(II), is formed at pH = 5.5. At pH = 6.0, dimeric copper(II) complexes of 2 and 3 are formed. Reaction at pH = 7 leads to a one-dimensional (1D) structure of 4. A further increase of the pH to 8.0 results in a two-dimensional (2D) structure of 5. Crystal data are monoclinic, space group P2/n, a = 13.992(4) Å, b = 5.7153(14) Å, c = 31.126(8) Å, β = 100.513(5)°, Z = 2 for 1, monoclinic, space group C2/c, a = 30.283(5) Å, b = 15.139(2) Å, c = 14.457(2) Å, β = 112.776(3)°, Z = 4 for 2, monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 5.8317(12) Å, b = 21.157(4) Å, c = 20.679(4) Å, β = 94.343(3)°, Z = 2 for 3, triclinic, space group P1̄, a = 14.016(3) Å, b = 18.492(4) Å, c = 19.353(4) Å, α = 66.220(3)°, β = 79.948(4)°, γ = 88.390(3)°, Z = 2 for 4, and monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 5.6880(16) Å, b = 17.917(5) Å, c = 20.904(6) Å, β = 92.959(5)°, Z = 2 for 5.

elements.content: Five Cu(II)/benzoate/4,4‘-bipy complexes have been synthesized under different pH conditions, revealing that the pH effect on the complexes' structures is attributed to the deprotonated extent of the organic acid; by changing the deprotonated extent of the organic acid, the pH value affects the coordination ability of the organic ligand to the metal ion and coordination mode of the 4,4‘-bipy ligand.

elements.content: Constructions of metal-involved supramolecular architectures based on crystal engineering are currently of interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and material science. In the effort to design and assemble such kinds of supramolecular architectures, not only a great many supramolecular architectures with intriguing topology have successfully been synthesized, but also several synthetic strategies, such as the symmetry interaction, directional bonding, and weak-link synthetic approaches, have been developed. Owing to the fact that the assembly of supramolecular architectures is easily affected by external physical or chemical stimuli, however, the reaction pathways frequently change case by case, resulting in poor selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Constructions of metal-involved supramolecular architectures based on crystal engineering are currently of interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and material science. In the effort to design and assemble such kinds of supramolecular architectures, not only a great many supramolecular architectures with intriguing topology have successfully been synthesized, but also several synthetic strategies, such as the symmetry interaction, directional bonding, and weak-link synthetic approaches, have been developed. Owing to the fact that the assembly of supramolecular architectures is easily affected by external physical or chemical stimuli, however, the reaction pathways frequently change case by case, resulting in poor selectivity.

elements.content: The pH value of the reaction, as one of the external stimuli, is especially important in the assembly of supramolecular architectures. It not only affects the ligand coordination ability but also its charge, the metal-to-ligand ratio, and consequently, the resulting structures. In this work, we chose the widely used organic ligand, 4,4‘-bipyridine (4,4‘-bipy), and carboxylate ligands as an example to show the role of the pH value of the reaction in controlling the structure of the supramolecular architecture and report here syntheses and crystal structures of [Cu(H2O)(benzoate)2(4,4‘-bipy)2](benzoic acid)2·(4,4‘-bipy)(1), [Cu2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)3]·(H2O)9 (2), [Cu2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)3] (3), [Cu3(H2O)4(benzoate)6(4,4‘-bipy)4.5]·(4,4‘-bipy)·(H2O)5 (4), and [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)2(benzoate)4(4,4‘-bipy)2] (5). Their structures range from a zero-dimensional (0D) mononuclear complex to a two-dimensional (2D) network, revealing the pH effect on the supramolecular architecture.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000−400 cm-1 with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer. The pH value of the reaction was measured with a Delta 320 meter.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a CE instruments EA 1110 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 with a Nicolet AVATAR FT-IR360 spectrometer. The pH value of the reaction was measured with a Delta 320 meter.

elements.content: Syntheses. (a) [Cu(H 2 O)(benzoate) 2 (4,4‘-bipy) 2 ](benzoic acid) 2 ·(4,4‘-bipy) (1). To 10 mL of methanol−water (1:1 (v/v)) solution was added benzoic acid (1.0 mmol, 0.122 g), 4,4‘-bipy (0.5 mmol, 0.08 g), and cupric acetate (0.5 mmol, 0.10 g) while stirring at room temperature. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to about 5.5 with ammonia solution (∼12%), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr, heated to 60 °C for 50 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C·h-1. The blue column crystals of 1 (weight 5.0 mg) were obtained in 1.92% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value of the reaction is about 5.5. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H48CuN6O9 (%):  C, 67.28 (67.09); H, 4.45 (4.54); N, 8.12 (8.26). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3424m, 3069w, 1684w, 1601s, 1566m, 1415m, 1379s, 1318w, 1274m, 1220m, 1069m, 811m, 723s, 636m, 485w.

elements.content: In the preparation of 1 − 5, a large number of green powders always accompanied. The elementary analysis for the green powders produced in each reaction indicates that they consist of very close ratio of C to N to H (C, 58.52%; N, 3.70%; H, 3.49%). From which, the mole ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate is about 1:4 and the formula for the green powder can be deduced as [Cu2(4,4‘-bipy)(benzoate)4(H2O)] (Calcd:  C, 58.39%; N, 3.59%; H, 3.84%). Consistently, the IR spectrum for the green powder also approved the presence of both 4,4‘-bipyridine and benzoate (Supporting Information).

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Data collections were performed on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD diffractometer at 123 K for complexes 1, 2, 4, and 5 and at 173 K for complex 3. Absorption corrections were applied by using the multiscan program SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods, and non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligand were generated geometrically (C−H, 0.96 Å). Crystal data as well as details of data collection and refinement for the complexes are summarized in Table

Description of Crystal Structures. The asymmetric unit in complex 1 consists of one copper(II) cation, two benzoates, two benzoic acids, two 4,4‘-bipy ligands, and one water molecule. Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 is a discrete mononuclear copper(II) unit with its copper(II) center coordinated by two 4,4‘-bipy ligands, two monodentate carboxylates of benzoates, and one water molecule in a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Benzoic acid is hydrogen-bonded to uncoordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand in the mononuclear copper(II) unit as shown in Figure . Connection of adjacent copper(II) complexes through hydrogen-bonding interactions between coordination water and carboxylate group (O1w···O12 = 2.675(3) Å, O1w−H1wa···O12 = 1.94(3) Å, <O1w−H1wa−O12 = 169(4)°) and the 4,4‘-bipy and carboxylate group (O22···N12 = 2.636(4) Å, O22−H22a···N12 = 1.95(4) Å, <O22−H22a−N12 = 175(5)°) generates a one-dimensional (1D) chain as shown in Figure . This 1D chain is further extended into a three-dimensional (3D) structure through C−H···π interaction between the coordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand and guest benzoic acid (C14−H14A···π (C23) = 2.817 Å, C14−H14A···π (C23) = 2.866 Å) and the hydrogen-bonding interaction between guest 4,4‘-bipy and coordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand (C12···N41 = 3.328 Å, H12a···N41 = 2.383 Å, <C12−H12a···N41 = 172.9°) as illustrated in Figure . The bond lengths of Cu−N, Cu−Ocarboxylate, and Cu−Owater are 1.974(3), 1.928(2), and 2.158(4) Å, respectively, comparable to those of 2.001(1), 1.938(1), and 2.141(2) Å in the five-coordinated complex of [Cu(2,4-pydca)2(H2O)]·(Et3NH)2 (2,4-pydca2- = pyridine-2,4-dicarboxylate).

Results and Discussion

 Description of Crystal Structures. The asymmetric unit in complex 1 consists of one copper(II) cation, two benzoates, two benzoic acids, two 4,4‘-bipy ligands, and one water molecule. Crystal structural analysis reveals that complex 1 is a discrete mononuclear copper(II) unit with its copper(II) center coordinated by two 4,4‘-bipy ligands, two monodentate carboxylates of benzoates, and one water molecule in a distorted square-pyramidal geometry. Benzoic acid is hydrogen-bonded to uncoordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand in the mononuclear copper(II) unit as shown in Figure . Connection of adjacent copper(II) complexes through hydrogen-bonding interactions between coordination water and carboxylate group (O1w⋅⋅⋅O12 = 2.675(3) Å, O1w-H1wa⋅⋅⋅O12 = 1.94(3) Å, <O1w-H1wa-O12 = 169(4)°) and the 4,4‘-bipy and carboxylate group (O22⋅⋅⋅N12 = 2.636(4) Å, O22-H22a⋅⋅⋅N12 = 1.95(4) Å, <O22-H22a-N12 = 175(5)°) generates a one-dimensional (1D) chain as shown in Figure . This 1D chain is further extended into a three-dimensional (3D) structure through C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction between the coordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand and guest benzoic acid (C14-H14A⋅⋅⋅π (C23) = 2.817 Å, C14-H14A⋅⋅⋅π (C23) =  2.866 Å) and the hydrogen-bonding interaction between guest 4,4‘-bipy and coordinated 4,4‘-bipy ligand (C12⋅⋅⋅N41 = 3.328 Å, H12a⋅⋅⋅N41 = 2.383 Å, <C12-H12a⋅⋅⋅N41 = 172.9°) as illustrated in Figure . The bond lengths of Cu-N, Cu-Ocarboxylate, and Cu-Owater are 1.974(3), 1.928(2), and 2.158(4) Å, respectively, comparable to those of 2.001(1), 1.938(1), and 2.141(2) Å in the five-coordinated complex of [Cu(2,4-pydca)2(H2O)]⋅(Et3NH)2 (2,4-pydca2- = pyridine-2,4-dicarboxylate).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit in complex 2 consists of 2 copper(II) cations, 4 benzoates, 3 4,4‘-bipy ligands, and 11 water molecules. Crystal structural analysis reveals that the central copper(II) ion in 2 is coordinated by two carboxylate groups from two benzoates in monodentate coordination mode, one water molecule and two nitrogen atoms, respectively, from two 4,4-bipy ligands in square-pyramidal geometry. Two copper(II) centers bridged by a 4,4‘-bipy ligand generate a dinuclear copper(II) unit as shown in Figure . Each dinuclear copper(II) unit connected with two adjacent ones through π···π stacking of benzoate (π···π = 3.368 Å) forms a 1D chain as shown in Figure . Interlocking the 1D chain through π···π stacking of 4,4‘-bipy ligand with the average inter-ring contacts of 3.705 Å and hydrogen-bonding interaction between water and the carboxylate group of the benzoate ligand (O1w···O12 = 2.725(3) Å, O1w−H1wa···O12 = 1.99(3) Å, <O1w−H1wa−O12 = 153(3)°, O2w···O12 = 2.722(3) Å, O2w−H2wa···O12 = 2.00(3) Å, <O2w−H2wa−O12 = 172(4)°, O3w···O22 = 2.695(3) Å, O3w−H3wa···O22 = 1.91(4) Å, <O3w−H3wa−O22 = 163(3)°, O5w···O21 = 2.824(2) Å, O5w−H5wa···O21 = 2.03(3) Å, <O5w−H5wa−O21 = 168(3)°) generates a 3D structure as illustrated in Figure . A water nonamer viewed as two water pentamers that shared a vertex was located in each cavity of the 3D structure as shown in Figure . The bond lengths are 2.0133(16) and 2.0262(16) Å for Cu−N, 1.9522(14)−2.6796(17) Å for Cu−Ocarboxylate, and 2.2161(17) Å for Cu−Owater, respectively, comparable to those of 1.993 and 2.002 Å for Cu−N, 1.980−2.611 Å for Cu−Ocarboxylate, and 2.268 Å for Cu−Owater in the complex of (L3)Py2Cu·H2O (L3 = HO2CC(Me)2OArOC(Me)2CO2H).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit in complex 3 consists of two copper(II) cations, four benzoates, and three 4,4‘-bipy ligands. Crystal structural analysis reveals that each copper(II) center in 3 is six-coordinated, respectively, by two chelate carboxylates and two 4,4‘-bipy ligands in distorted octahedral geometry. Two copper(II) centers bridged by a 4,4‘-bipy ligand generate a copper(II) dimer similar to that in 2 as shown in Figure . Each of the copper(II) dimers vertically linking with four adjacent ones through C−H···π interaction forms a 2D structure as illustrated in Figure , which further extended into a 3D structure through the hydrogen-bonding interaction between the carboxylate group from one layer and the C−H group from the adjacent layer as shown in Figure . Although the dinuclear copper(II) unit in 3 is very similar to that in 2, both the 2D and 3D structures in 3 are significantly different from those in 2, indicating that solvent water molecules play a key role in the construction of supramolecular architectures. The bond lengths are 2.0032(16) and 2.0069(16) Å for Cu−N and 1.9652(13), 1.9508(13), 2.5502(17), and 2.6074(18) Å for Cu−Ocarboxylate, comparable to those of 1.987(4) Å for Cu−N and 1.972(3)−2.683(4) Å in the complex of [Cd2Cu(HBPTC)2(μ2-4,4‘-bipy)2(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)2] n (BPTC = 3,3‘,4,4‘-benzophenone-tetracarboxylate).

elements.content: Complex 4 consists of 3 copper(II) cations, 5.5 4,4‘-bipy ligands, 6 benzoates, and 9 water molecules. Crystal structural analysis reveals that there are 3.5 independent copper(II) centers in the asymmetry unit in 4. The independent copper(II) center (Cu3) is six-coordinated by two water molecules at apical positions and two monodentate benzoates and two 4,4‘-bipy ligands at basal positions in octahedral geometry (namely, A type), forming a mononuclear copper(II) complex; the independent copper(II) center (Cu2) is five-coordinated by one water molecule at the apical position and two monodentate benzoates and two 4,4‘-bipy ligands at basal positions in distorted square-pyramidal geometry (namely, B type), resulting a mononuclear copper(II) complex as shown in Figure . Interestingly, the coordination geometries of the independent copper(II) center Cu1 and Cu4 (with half occupancy) are very similar to those of Cu3 and Cu2, respectively. As a result, the 1D chain of [Cu3(H2O)4(benzoate)6(4,4‘-bipy)4.5] formed by Cu1 and Cu2 can be viewed as A- and B-type mononuclear copper(II) complexes connected in AABAAB fashion as shown in Figure . This fact implies that the generation of the 1D chain is constructed of simple coordination complexes. The bond lengths of Cu−N, Cu−Ocarboxylate, and Cu−Owater in the A type are 2.005(3), 1.953(2), and 2.510(3) Å, respectively, comparable to those of 1.983, 1.925, and 2.529 Å of {[Cu3Mo2(NO3)2O8(C10H8N2)3]·4H2O} n . The bond lengths of Cu−N, Cu−Ocarboxylate, and Cu−Owater in the B type are 2.028(3)−2.033(3), 1.937(2)−1.943(2), and 2.345(3) Å, respectively, comparable to those of 1.958−2.017, 1.915−1.949, and 2.348 Å of [Cu(Bic)(Bz)]ClO4 (Bic = N,N-bis(2-hydroxyethyl)glycinate, Bz = benzimidazole).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of complex 5 consists of a linear trinuclear copper(II) unit of [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)2(benzoate)4] and two 4,4‘-bipy ligands. In the linear trinuclear copper(II) unit, Cu1 and Cu1a are, respectively, coordinated by two carboxylates, respectively, from two benzoates in monodentate coordination mode, and Cu1−Cu2 and Cu2−Cu1a pairs are, respectively, linked by a hydroxyl bridge. Completing the coordination of each cooper(II) atom in the trinuclear copper(II) unit through Cu1 and Cu1a, respectively, coordinated by one 4,4‘-bipy ligand and one water molecule and Cu2 to two 4,4‘-bipy ligands results in each copper(II) atom locating in distorted square-pyramidal geometry as shown in Figure . The Cu···Cu distance is 3.118 Å, which is a little shorter than the sum of the atomic radii of two copper atoms (3.14 Å), indicating that there is a weak interaction between the two copper atoms. It was mentioned that, although a similar linear trinuclear copper(II) unit has been reported previously, trinuclear copper(II) interconnected by hydroxyl and water bridges remains rare. The 2D structure of 5 can be viewed as the connection of each of the trinuclear copper(II) units with four adjacent trinuclear copper(II) ones through four 4,4‘-bipy ligands as illustrated in Figure . Trinuclear copper(II) is a common subunit to construct 1D polynuclear copper(II)-based coordination polymers; however, the utilization of a trinuclear copper(II) unit to construct 2D or 3D polynuclear copper(II)-based coordination polymer remains a challenge. The bond lengths of Cu−N and Cu−O are 1.997(3)−2.002(3) and 1.907(2)−2.843(3) Å, respectively, comparable to 2.022−2.049 and 1.955−2.833 Å of [Cu2(2-MPI)2(H2O)6](NO3)4(2-MPI)4(H2O)2 (2-MPI = 2-methylpyrido[2,3-d] imidazole).

elements.content: Influence of the pH Value of the Reaction on the Structure of the Complexes. Since the only difference in the synthetic condition in complexes 1 − 5 is that of the pH value of the reactions (Scheme ), it is clear that the pH value of the reaction plays a key role in controlling the structures of the complexes. Based on the structures of 1 − 5, we found that the pH influence on the structure of the complexes is, in fact, its effect on the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate. As demonstrated in 1 − 5, the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate ranges from 1:1 to 1:2 with the increase of the pH value of the reaction. Clearly, the pH value influence on the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate in the complexes is attributed to its effect on deprotonation of benzoic acid, since high pH value will favor the deprotonation of the benzoic acid, while deprotonation of the organic acid will favor its coordination to the metal ion on the basis of acid−base chemistry and soft and hard acid-based principle. It was mentioned that although there is no change in the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate among complexes 2, 3, and 4 at pH ranges from 6.0 to 7.5, the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate (1:1.5) in the 1D chain in 4 is significantly higher than that (1:1.33) in 2 and 3 and consistent with that high pH value favors the deprotonation of the organic acid. Interestingly, in addition to increasing the ratio of 4,4‘-bipy to benzoate in the complexes, high pH value of the reaction significantly enhances the tendency of 4,4‘-bipy as a bridging ligand as demonstrated in the mononuclear copper(II) structure of 1 (pH < 6.0, no 4,4‘-bipy ligand functioned as a bridge), dimer copper(II) structures of 2 and 3 (pH = 6.0, only one 4,4‘-bipy ligand functioned as a bridge), and 1D chain structure of 4 (pH = 7.5, all 4,4‘-bipy ligands functioned as bridges). Owing to the impossibility to increase the concentration of copper(II) ion at higher pH condition in this system, the increased tendency of 4,4‘-bipy to act as a bridge ligand at high pH value was attributed to formation of hydrogen-bonding interaction between 4,4‘-bipy and benzoic acid that decreased at high pH value, since the concentration of benzoic acid at high pH value is much lower than that at lower pH condition. This is indeed the case and is demonstrated from the crystal structure of 1, in which it is the hydrogen-bonding interaction between the 4,4‘-bipy and benzoic acid that prevents the 4,4‘-bipy ligand forming a bridge, resulting in a mononuclear copper(II) complex.

elements.content: We, based on copper(II) ion, benzoic acid, and 4,4‘-bipy ligand, have synthesized five complexes at different pH conditions. Their structures range from a 0D mononuclear complex to a 2D network, showing the pH effect on the structures of the complexes. Through investigation on their structural differences, we reveal that the pH effect on the structures of the complexes is attributed to its effect on the deprotonated extent of the organic acid, and by changing the deprotonated extent of the organic acid, the pH value of the reaction not only affects the coordination ability of the organic ligand to metal ion but also the coordination mode of the 4,4‘-bipy ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We, based on copper(II) ion, benzoic acid, and 4,4‘-bipy ligand, have synthesized five complexes at different pH conditions. Their structures range from a 0D mononuclear complex to a 2D network, showing the pH effect on the structures of the complexes. Through investigation on their structural differences, we reveal that the pH effect on the structures of the complexes is attributed to its effect on the deprotonated extent of the organic acid, and by changing the deprotonated extent of the organic acid, the pH value of the reaction not only affects the coordination ability of the organic ligand to metal ion but also the coordination mode of the 4,4‘-bipy ligand.

Syntheses. (a) [Cu(H 2 O)(benzoate) 2 (4,4‘-bipy) 2 ](benzoic acid) 2 ·(4,4‘-bipy) (1). To 10 mL of methanol−water (1:1 (v/v)) solution was added benzoic acid (1.0 mmol, 0.122 g), 4,4‘-bipy (0.5 mmol, 0.08 g), and cupric acetate (0.5 mmol, 0.10 g) while stirring at room temperature. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to about 5.5 with ammonia solution (∼12%), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr, heated to 60 °C for 50 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C·h-1. The blue column crystals of 1 (weight 5.0 mg) were obtained in 1.92% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value of the reaction is about 5.5. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H48CuN6O9 (%):  C, 67.28 (67.09); H, 4.45 (4.54); N, 8.12 (8.26). IR (KBr, cm-1):  3424m, 3069w, 1684w, 1601s, 1566m, 1415m, 1379s, 1318w, 1274m, 1220m, 1069m, 811m, 723s, 636m, 485w.

(b) [Cu 2 (H 2 O) 2 (benzoate) 4 (4,4‘-bipy) 3 ]·(H 2 O) 9 (2) and [Cu 2 (benzoate) 4 (4,4‘-bipy) 3 ] (3). Complex 2 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 6.0 with ammonia solution (∼12%). The blue long column crystals of 2 (weight 4.9 mg) were obtained in 1.55% yield (based on benzoate ligand). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H66Cu2N6O19 (%):  C, 54.50 (53.08); H, 5.20 (4.68); N, 6.57 (6.41). (KBr, cm-1):  3423m, 3074w, 1610s, 1561m, 1490w, 1408m, 1375s, 1218w, 1069w, 1030w, 810w, 722m, 684w, 622w, 497w. In the preparation of 2, the blue purple column crystals of 3 (weight 5.1 mg) accompany the appearance of 2 in 1.89% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value of the reaction is about 6.0. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H44 Cu2N6O8 (%):  C, 64.44 (64.59); H, 4.07 (4.15); N, 7.78 (7.72). (KBr, cm-1):  3438w, 3078w, 1603s, 1569m, 1494w, 1451w, 1407m, 1373s, 1215w, 1066w, 1023w, 847w, 823m, 720s, 687w, 624w, 501w. The separation of 2 and 3 is based on their shape. Compound 2 crystallized in blue long column crystals, whereas 3 crystallized in purple podgy-like ones.

(c) [Cu 3 (H 2 O) 4 (benzoate) 6 (4,4‘-bipy) 4.5 ]·(4,4‘-bipy)·(H 2 O) 5 (4). Complex 4 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 7.5 with ammonia solution (∼12%). The blue block crystals of 4 (weight 2.0 mg) were obtained in 0.61% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value for the reaction is about 7.5.

(d) [Cu 3 (OH) 2 (H 2 O) 2 (benzoate) 4 (4,4‘-bipy) 2 ] (5). Complex 5 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 8.0 with ammonia solution (∼12%). The blue column crystals of 5 (weight 9.9 mg) were obtained in 3.75% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value for the reaction is about 7.9. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C48H42Cu3N4O12 (%):  C, 54.52 (54.91); H, 4.00 (3.91); N, 5.30 (5.29). (KBr, cm-1):  3311m, 3052m, 3015w, 1669w, 1600s, 1563s, 1497w, 1419m, 1386s, 1225m, 1065w, 1026w, 937w, 840w, 810m, 718s, 769m, 644m, 571w, 492m, 419w.

Syntheses. (a) [Cu(H  2  O)(benzoate)  2  (4,4‘-bipy)  2  ](benzoic acid)  2 ⋅(4,4‘-bipy) (1). To 10 mL of methanol-water (1:1 (v/v)) solution was added benzoic acid (1.0 mmol, 0.122 g), 4,4‘-bipy (0.5 mmol, 0.08 g), and cupric acetate (0.5 mmol, 0.10 g) while stirring at room temperature. When the pH value of the mixture was adjusted to about 5.5 with ammonia solution (~12%), the cloudy solution was put into a 25 mL Teflon-lined Parr, heated to 60 °C for 50 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2 °C⋅h-1. The blue column crystals of 1 (weight 5.0 mg) were obtained in 1.92% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value of the reaction is about 5.5. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H48CuN6O9 (%): C, 67.28 (67.09); H, 4.45 (4.54); N, 8.12 (8.26). IR (KBr, cm-1): 3424m, 3069w, 1684w, 1601s, 1566m, 1415m, 1379s, 1318w, 1274m, 1220m, 1069m, 811m, 723s, 636m, 485w. 

 (b) [Cu  2  (H  2  O)  2  (benzoate)  4  (4,4‘-bipy)  3  ]⋅(H  2  O)  9   (2) and [Cu  2  (benzoate)  4  (4,4‘-bipy)  3  ] (3). Complex 2 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 6.0 with ammonia solution (~12%). The blue long column crystals of 2 (weight 4.9 mg) were obtained in 1.55% yield (based on benzoate ligand). Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H66Cu2N6O19 (%): C, 54.50 (53.08); H, 5.20 (4.68); N, 6.57 (6.41). (KBr, cm-1): 3423m, 3074w, 1610s, 1561m, 1490w, 1408m, 1375s, 1218w, 1069w, 1030w, 810w, 722m, 684w, 622w, 497w. In the preparation of 2, the blue purple column crystals of 3 (weight 5.1 mg) accompany the appearance of 2 in 1.89% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value of the reaction is about 6.0. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C58H44 Cu2N6O8 (%): C, 64.44 (64.59); H, 4.07 (4.15); N, 7.78 (7.72). (KBr, cm-1): 3438w, 3078w, 1603s, 1569m, 1494w, 1451w, 1407m, 1373s, 1215w, 1066w, 1023w, 847w, 823m, 720s, 687w, 624w, 501w. The separation of 2 and 3 is based on their shape. Compound 2 crystallized in blue long column crystals, whereas 3 crystallized in purple podgy-like ones. 

 (c) [Cu  3  (H  2  O)  4  (benzoate)  6  (4,4‘-bipy)  4.5  ]⋅(4,4‘-bipy)⋅(H  2  O)  5   (4). Complex 4 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 7.5 with ammonia solution (~12%). The blue block crystals of 4 (weight 2.0 mg) were obtained in 0.61% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value for the reaction is about 7.5. 

 (d) [Cu  3  (OH)  2  (H  2  O)  2  (benzoate)  4  (4,4‘-bipy)  2  ] (5). Complex 5 was synthesized in the similar way as that described for 1, except that the pH value of the reaction was adjusted to 8.0 with ammonia solution (~12%). The blue column crystals of 5 (weight 9.9 mg) were obtained in 3.75% yield (based on benzoate ligand). The final pH value for the reaction is about 7.9. Anal. Calcd (Found) for C48H42Cu3N4O12 (%): C, 54.52 (54.91); H, 4.00 (3.91); N, 5.30 (5.29). (KBr, cm-1): 3311m, 3052m, 3015w, 1669w, 1600s, 1563s, 1497w, 1419m, 1386s, 1225m, 1065w, 1026w, 937w, 840w, 810m, 718s, 769m, 644m, 571w, 492m, 419w.
